Award.AwardTitle: Readout Systems for Cryogenic Dark Matter Detectors/SuperCDMS SNOLAB
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of normal atoms, but must be otherwise undetected elementary "dark matter" particles that do not emit or absorb light. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays. Direct detection of WIMP dark matter would solve a fundamental mystery in particle physics and cosmology, providing a unique window to learning about the primary matter constituent of the Universe and of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. This award will support students and scientists working on the SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment that aims to achieve world-leading sensitivity for dark matter searches in the 1-10 GeV/c2 mass range.

The impact of the SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment extends beyond the search for dark matter. The CU Denver group prepares undergraduates for graduate education or careers in technical fields through their integral involvement in all R&D activities. Undergraduate students, working closely with the PI, will study the sensitivity of the SuperCDMS SNOLAB SQUIDs to ambient magnetic fields and the associated degradation of sensitivity (increased noise levels) when operated in a lightly-shielded magnetic environment. The PI participates in outreach activities with two local magnet schools.

The experiment will be located at SNOLAB, in Ontario, Canada, the deepest underground laboratory in North America. This support will primarily allow the PI and his students to conduct the specific responsibilities this group has agreed to undertake within the collaboration. Among the collaboration responsibilities, CU Denver serves as the primary facility for post-fabrication SQUID verification of all devices to be used in SuperCDMS SNOLAB and test facilities, and is heavily involved in design of and measurements on the readout electronics. The CU Denver group will participate in the pre-operation and commissioning activities for SuperCDMS SNOLAB, specifically integration of the tower electronics, the readout electronics, and the DAQ, and installation and commissioning of the experiment at SNOLAB.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synopsis:     According to astronomical observations, approximately 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of ordinary particles, but exists in some as yet unknown form, which we call dark matter. Deciphering the nature of dark matter is of fundamental importance to several branches of science, including cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that dark matter comprises Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, produced moments after the Big Bang. Such particles would interact only through gravity and the weak nuclear force. If this hypothesis is correct, then the presence of WIMPs in our galaxy should be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in a terrestrial detector. The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration and its successor, the SuperCDMS Collaboration, have pioneered the use of low-temperature phonon-mediated devices to search for the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and to distinguish them from background interactions such as electron or gamma-ray scattering, which predominate.

Intellectual Merit:     This award provides support for the University of Colorado Denver (CU Denver) SuperCDMS group that, in conjunction with other SuperCDMS collaboration awards, has enabled the SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment, a second-generation (G2) dark matter detector focusing on low-mass WIMPs. The silicon and germanium crystals that comprise the primary detectors for dark matter interactions are operated near absolute zero and each interaction produces a brief, tiny temperature rise. While most interactions are from the background (electrons and gamma rays), some should be WIMPs. These temperature fluctuations, related to phonons, are converted to small electric current pulses. These pulses are, in turn, amplified to produce signals that can be digitized and recorded by room temperature electronics. The primary device used in this conversion process is a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID), an extremely sensitive sensor of magnetic fields and electric currents. The SQUID and the room-temperature electronics form the basis of the readout system for this channel of dark matter interactions with the detectors. Integration of this preamplifier with the detector, cold hardware, and other room-temperature electronics is essential to the success of the experiment and falls within the expertise of the PI and the CU Denver group. In addition, while the SQUIDs are used in this application primarily to sense the detector current pulses, they nonetheless remain somewhat sensitive to environmental magnetic fields. Such sensitivity can degrade the intended detector performance and can be mitigated by a thorough understanding of the SQUID response. To this end, a special apparatus was designed that would allow us to both model and measure the SQUID response to calibrated magnetic fields. The scope of this project was limited to the development of the model and to the design of an oversized prototype of this experiment to later confirm accuracy of the model.

Broader Impact:     These technical developments will have the broader impact of extending the limits of phonon-mediated detectors. Phonon-mediated detectors have increasing utility in many areas of physics and astrophysics, from optical astronomy to x-rays and cosmic microwave backgrounds studies. The CU Denver group focuses on undergraduate participation, educating undergraduate students majoring in physics and electrical engineering in the use of techniques at the leading edge of measurement technologies and providing them a solid foundation in laboratory research.
